column1: The Western Libya campaign was a military campaign initiated on 4 April 2019 by the Operation Flood of Dignity (Arabic: عملية طوفان الكرامة‎) of the Libyan National Army
column2: which represents the Libyan House of Representatives
column3: to capture the western region of Libya and eventually the capital Tripoli held by the United Nations Security Council-recognised Government of National Accord. As of 4 June 2020
column4: the Government of National Accord has regained control over all of Tripoli and the LNA forces have withdrawn from the capital
column5: after fourteen months of fighting.The offensive resulted in over 2
column6: 356 dead. It began on 4 April 2019
column7: 10 days before the Libyan National Conference for organising presidential and parliamentary elections in Libya had been planned to take place
column8: and five days after the first session of the 2019 Libyan local elections was held successfully. As a result of the offensive
column9: United Nations Support Mission in Libya postponed the forthcoming Libyan National Conference.War crimes and crimes against humanity that take place during the conflict are covered by the mandate of the International Criminal Court investigation in Libya under United Nations Security Council Resolution 1970.

column1: Following the overthrow and death of Muammar Gaddafi and the fall of the Great Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya in 2011
column2: political and military control in Libya were in a state of flux. Fighting between different factions escalated in 2014
column3: with the House of Representatives
column4: based in the eastern city of Tobruk
column5: being the main political force claiming to be the legitimate government of Libya. The House of Representatives was supported by Field Marshal Khalifa Haftar's Libyan National Army. In early 2016 a rival government
column6: the Government of National Accord (GNA)
column7: was established in Tripoli with the backing of the UN and several countries. There were multiple attempts to negotiate between the two governments and organise new elections throughout 2017 and 2018. Haftar and GNA Prime Minister Fayez al-Sarraj met and spoke with each other twice for negotiations
column8: in November 2018 and February 2019. The Supreme Judicial Council of Libya
column9: created in 2011
column10: retained its structure as a single national body despite the political split
column11: and in 2019 went through Libya-wide "transparent elections" and a "peaceful transfer of power".

column2: 000 Libyans and online consultations with 130
column3: 000 Libyans during 2018–2019
column4: coordinated by the United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) and the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue
column5: led to a plan to hold the Libyan National Conference in Ghadames during 14–16 April 2019 in order to recommend to the Libyan House of Representatives and High Council of State methods and dates for holding 2019 presidential and parliamentary elections in Libya. The first batch of the 2019 municipal elections in Libya took place on 30 March 2019. Other aims of the conference
column6: to which representatives of all political factions were invited
column7: included creating a unity government between Sarraj and Haftar and proposing a framework for creating a new constitution. In March 2019
column8: the advance of Haftar's forces in southern Libya during the preceding few months started to cause concern for the organisers of the conference. Ghassan Salamé
column9: head of UNSMIL
column10: stated on 4 April 2019 that the conference would be postponed because of the outburst of military events
column11: but that it would be held "as soon as possible because we do not have the right to allow this historic opportunity to be corrupted. At the same time
column12: we cannot ask for the presence of the Conference
column13: with the [cannons] firing and the raids ongoing
column14: without making sure that all those who are willing to respond to this historic national duty from all regions of the country are able to ensure their safety and freedom by expressing their opinion."

column2: an audio recording was published on Facebook by Marshal Haftar declaring war on the UN-recognised Government of National Accord and announcing that the LNA would militarily take over the capital city Tripoli. In response
column3: the government in Tripoli
column4: led by Prime Minister Fayez al-Sarraj and the Presidential Council ordered a general mobilisation of all of its security forces. On 6 April
column5: Prime Minister Sarraj
column6: as supreme commander of the Libyan Army
column7: created a joint operations room under the western military region commander
column8: Major General Osama al-Juwaili
column9: to coordinate their operations.

column2: during the years prior to the April 2019 attack on Tripoli
column3: Haftar received long-term support from French authorities
column4: including French "advisers
column5: clandestine operatives
column6: and special forces" helping the LNA's military operations in the east and south of Libya. Three of the French special-forces soldiers died in a helicopter accident near Benghazi in July 2016. Bloomberg News stated that the al-Sarraj administration had long-term support from Italian authorities. The Economist argued that a May 2018 meeting between al-Sarraj and Haftar
column7: hosted by French president Emmanuel Macron in the context of French-Italian rivalry with regards to Libya
column8: "undermined" the efforts of Ghassan Salamé in facilitating the organising of the Libyan National Conference by Libyans. The Economist pointed to the Greenstream pipeline natural gas pipeline and French and Italian crude oil interests in Libya as significant factors in the two countries' relations with Libyan political forces in 2018.Bloomberg News described Russia
column9: Egypt and the United Arab Emirates as "backers" of Haftar. Prior to the LNA attack on Tripoli
column10: the Saudi Arabian government gave twenty million US dollars to the LNA in support of the attack
column11: "to buy the loyalty of tribal leaders
column13: and other military purposes."On 27 December 2019  Bloomberg News reported that Turkey intended to deploy its navy to protect Tripoli and send troops to help train GNA forces. Additionally Turkmen rebel groups fighting in northern Syria were expected to transfer to Tripoli. By 29 December
column14: 650 Syrian National Army personnel (also called: Syrian National Army) had arrived in Libya and were stationed on the eastern frontline in Tripoli.

column1: 4 AprilOn the first day of the offensive
column2: 4 April 2019
column3: the LNA captured Gharyan. Haftar urged pro-GNA militias to surrender
column4: saying "Those who lay down their weapons are safe
column5: and those who raise the white banner are safe." Interior minister Fathi Bashagha condemned the offensive
column6: declaring that "We will not be subdued by any use of force by any side or any person. And if anyone is willing to use force against us we're ready for sacrifice but we will not give up on democracy which we've always wanted from the beginning."

column2: the Libyan National Army stated that they had captured Qasr bin Ghashir
column3: Wadi al-Rabie and Suq al-Khamis. LNA then marched toward Tripoli from several directions
column4: reaching the city's outskirts after receiving orders to capture the city. The LNA reported asserting control over the town of ‘Aziziya. The LNA briefly captured a key checkpoint
column5: known as Gate 27
column6: on the road between Tripoli and Tunisia
column7: but withdrew overnight. The GNA interior ministry ordered all of its forces to be placed on maximum alert. The United Nations Security Council scheduled an emergency meeting on the same day to discuss the recent developments in Libya. Later in the day the LNA reported capturing the village of Suq al-Khamis
column8: located 20 kilometres (20
column9: 000 m) south of Tripoli
column10: after clashes with pro-GNA militias. Meanwhile
column13: met with UN Secretary General António Guterres in the former's office in Tobruk. During the late hours of the day a battle broke out over Tripoli International Airport
column14: in which LNA forces were able to successfully capture the airfield and defend it from a GNA counter-attack.

column2: the LNA air force declared western Libya a no-fly zone and began to engage GNA targets
column3: after GNA jets targeted LNA positions in Mizdah and Suq al-Khamis. Haftar issued orders against using the LNA's aircraft in battle. The LNA reported recapturing Gate 27
column4: as well as asserting control over Salah al-Din and Ain Zara neighbourhood in southern Tripoli
column5: after pro-GNA militias surrendered to the LNA. By nightfall forces loyal to the GNA launched a counterattack on the airport in southern Tripoli
column6: which was repelled by the advancing LNA
column7: according to Haftar.

column1: A US military contingent and a contingent of Indian police peacekeepers were evacuated from Tripoli.Colonel Mohamed Gnounou
column2: the GNA military spokesman
column3: announced that they started a counteroffensive to reclaim the territories in Tripoli taken by the LNA
column4: dubbed "Operation Volcano of Anger". The UN mission in Libya asked for a two-hour ceasefire in south Tripoli to evacuate civilians.In an official declaration
column5: the Ministry of Health of the GNA declared their casualties at 21 dead and 27 wounded.The LNA conducted an airstrike against a GNA position in southern Tripoli
column6: the Bab al-Azizia military compound
column7: the first LNA airstrike to target a part of the city. It is thought that Haftar has a superior air force
column8: supplied by the United Arab Emirates
column9: although the Libyan Air Force is nominally loyal to the GNA.By the end of the day
column12: reported that the LNA reached the Fernaj neighbourhood of Tripoli and are advancing through the eastern neighbourhoods of the city.

column1: 8 April-9 AprilThe GNA airforce launched an air strike on the early hours of Monday on al-Watiyah
column2: the only airbase captured by LNA since the launch of the operation
column3: located 130 kilometres (80 miles) southeast of Tripoli.As part of the operation Volcano of Anger launched by GNA
column4: Mistrata militias mobilized on the frontlines of Tripoli to prevent the LNA from capturing it.LNA forces under Hifter conducted an airstrike against the GNA-held Mitiga International Airport in Tripoli
column5: Libya's last functioning civilian airport
column6: on 8 April. The closure left Misrata Airport
column7: located 200 km (125 miles) to the east down the coast
column8: as the nearest airport for Tripoli residents. UN special representative for Libya Ghassan Salamé condemned the attack as "a serious violation of international humanitarian law." Wolfram Lacher
column9: a scholar of Libya at the German Institute for International and Security Affairs
column10: said that the strike showed Hifter's willingness "to reduce Tripoli to rubble so that he can rule Libya
column11: which is the only option he has left now anyway." Flights were temporarily suspended; by 9 April
column12: a coalition of local and regional militias and GNA forces had pushed Hifter's forces from the airport
column14: with clashes continuing in multiple locations on the southern fringes of Tripoli. On 8 April
column15: the LGA said 19 of its soldiers died in recent days in the fighting in and around Tripoli
column16: while a spokesman for the GNA's said that "fighting in the south of the capital had killed at least 25 people
column18: and wounded 80."From the beginning of April 2019 to mid-May 2019
column19: southern Tripoli's Yarmouk military camp/barracks had changed hands between the GNA and the LNA at least five times.The LNA used BM-21 Grad MRLs against GNA positions in retaliation for GNA airstrikes.According to Libya al-Ahrar TV as cited by The Libya Observer
column20: a team of French "military experts" arrived in Gharyan and created a "control room to monitor the attack on Tripoli".

column1: 10 AprilThe GNA reported bombing LNA targets within the LNA-held town of Gharyan. The LNA announced that they have captured the 4th Brigade Headquarters in the town of Azizya after fierce fighting with the GNA. The UNHCR attempted to evacuate detained refugees from the Qasir bin Gashir detention center
column2: after it became stuck in crossfire between the two sides. Reports suggest most detainees were transferred to Sekah Road detention center
column3: but around 120 people were left behind and were still in the Qasir bin Gashir detention center by the morning. During the afternoon
column4: the LNA air force conducted an airstrike against GNA targets near Tripoli airport. By sunset
column5: LNA spokesperson
column6: Brig. Gen. Ahmed al-Mismari
column7: stated that the LNA have secured al-Yarmouk camp and are advancing toward the Dabali military camp. He also reported that the LNA have arrested pro-GNA "african mercenaries" at Tripoli Int'l Airport. Shortly thereafter
column8: al-Mismari stated that the LNA have shot down a GNA Aero L-39 Albatros that attempted to relocate from Misrata to Tripoli.

column1: 11 AprilThe Chief of the GNA Tripoli Military Zone
column2: Maj. Gen. Abdul-Basit Marwan
column3: stated that the LNA were shelling GNA positions in southern Tripoli with BM-21 Grad MRLs. The GNA claimed several airstrikes on LNA targets in Suq al-Khamis and Tarhuna city. The LNA retaliated by launching an airstrike on GNA targets in the contested Ayn Zara region. A GNA spokesman reported that the GNA have recaptured Wadie Alrabie
column4: Bridge 27
column5: Bridge of Souq Al-Ahad and Tripoli International Airport. Brig. Gen. Al-Mismari
column6: LNA spokesperson
column7: reported that the "things on the ground are in favour of the [Libyan National] army
column8: adding that they have seized 14 GNA armoured vehicles and tanks, positioning themselves a mere 2 km from Tripoli's city centre after a GNA retreat. He stated that Tripoli Int'l Airport is still a fire zone
column9: but did not comment on who controlled it at that time. He also promised to surprise everyone" with a plan to seize all of Tripoli. By nightfall
column10: the GNA claimed that it negotiated the surrender of soldiers belonging to the LNA 8th brigade in Ayn Zara
column11: after they were left without fuel or ammunition for more than a day. The LNA shelled the contested town of Al Swatani. An LNA spokesman stated that the Libyan National Army has issued an arrest warrant for Fayez al-Sarraj

column1: 12 AprilThe LNA conducted an airstrike against the GNA in Abdel Samad Camp
column2: south of Zuwarah. Heavy gunfire and explosions were reported from downtown Tripoli. The LNA stated that they have received major military reinforcements
column3: that they have killed dozens of GNA fighters in the previous day's offensive
column4: and that the LNA 9th brigade is advancing in the Al-Khalla region. It also reported that several young GNA fighters defected to the LNA. The LNA air force conducted air raids against GNA targets in Wadi Al Rabie
column5: south of Tripoli. In the late afternoon
column6: the LNA conducted airstrikes against a GNA military camp
column7: as well as an arms cache in the North-East Tripoli neighbourhood of Tajura. Explosions were reported at GNA-held Mitiga International Airport. Conflicting reports emerged as to whether they were from an LNA airstrike on the airport or as a result of GNA anti-aircraft guns firing. The LNA claimed that residential houses and civilian buildings in LNA-held suburbs of Tripoli were subjected to bombardment by the GNA. LNA spokesman
column8: Brig. Gen. Al-Mismari
column9: accused former President of Sudan
column11: of sending two planes loaded with 28 fighters
column12: as well as a large amount of weapons and ammunition
column13: from Khartoum to GNA-held Mitiga International Airport on 28 March. Fathi Bashagha
column14: Interior Minister of the Presidential Council
column15: stated on 12 April that the United Arab Emirates sent military equipment to the LNA at Benina International Airport in Benghazi. The UNHCR called for the release and evacuation of detained refugees held in wartorn areas. The UNHCR confirmed that 728 people were still trapped in the contested Qasir Bin Gashir detention center
column16: stating that it attempted to evacuate them to the Zintan detention center the previous day. The detainees refused to go
column17: insisting that they be evacuated out of Libya.

column1: 13 AprilSpeaker of the Tobruk-based House of Representatives
column2: Aguila Saleh Issa
column3: called for a partial lifting of the international arms embargo imposed on Libya
column4: to allow countries to legally arm the Libyan National Army. He stated that the Tobruk-based government intends to hold elections after capturing Tripoli. The LNA conducted several airstrikes on GNA targets in the southern party of the city
column5: amid intense street battles between the two sides. The World Health Organization delivered medical kits to local hospitals
column6: but cautioned that Tripoli only has enough medical supplies for two weeks. GNA forces once again took control of Al-Yarmouk camp.

column2: reporting that internationally designated terrorist groups were fighting alongside the GNA in Tripoli. The GNA Presidential Council denied the claims. A GNA plane targeted an LNA military post in Southern Tripoli. President of Egypt
column3: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi
column4: met with LNA Field Marshal Khalifa Haftar in Cairo. An intensification of LNA air force activity was reported
column5: with LNA Mi-35 helicopters and Su-22 bombers targeting numerous GNA positions in Azizya
column6: Wadi Al Rabie
column7: the 4th Brigade HQ
column8: Al Sawani
column9: Ayn Zara and Tajura. The LNA reportedly made advances toward the center of Tripoli
column10: as well as Salah Al-Din. The LNA recaptured Yarmouk camp
column11: as well as several other military camps in the area and is positioning itself toward capturing the Green Plateau of Tripoli. The LNA was reported to have taken control of Spring Valley Bridge in the south of the capital. The LNA sent military reinforcements to Ra's Lanuf and Es Sider oil ports
column12: in anticipation of a counter-attack by the GNA. A LNA warplane crashed in southern Tripoli. The GNA claimed to have shot it down. A video was later released allegedly showing missiles being fired at the plane
column13: with one hitting the aircraft. Images released from local residents purported to show both the pilot and co-pilot successfully ejecting from the aircraft and deploying their parachutes. LNA Brig. Gen. Al-Mismari confirmed that the aircraft was shot down by a missile
column14: fired by GNA forces from a suburb of Tripoli. He added that the pilot was alive and in good health. He also accused a GNA militia commander of planning to bring over 350 mercenaries to the capital to fight the LNA. Detainees at the contested Qasir bin Gashir detention center told Al Jazeera that they have been abandoned by their GNA guards since the previous day and were left to fend for themselves in the crossfire. They stated that there were still 728 detained refugees residing in the camp. They accused the GNA of subjecting them to "years of much torture and suffering"
column15: reiterating their desire to leave the country entirely.

column1: 15 AprilHeavy clashes were reported between LNA and GNA forces in Tripoli's Ayn Zara suburb. The LNA military information division stated that "large reinforcements" had arrived in LNA-controlled Gharyan and were preparing to join the assault on the capital. A GNA official claimed that more than 3 million books were destroyed as a result of shelling on a building belonging to the Libyan ministry of education. Both sides accused each other of the attack. A new spokesperson for the GNA Presidential Council (the previous spokesman
column2: who was born in Eastern Libya
column3: was replaced without explanation) accused foreign governments and "statelets" of plotting to cause instability in Libya. He claimed that GNA forces were "constantly advancing on all axes"
column4: managing to "defeat the aggressor force" and that they were able to "inflict on the [LNA] aggressor militias huge casualty." He also accused the LNA of various war crimes. GNA head
column5: Fayez al-Sarraj
column6: vowed to have all LNA leaders and commanders involved in the offensive prosecuted.Bombardments of Tripoli with Grad dockets and missiles continued with late-night shelling on April 15. Four people were reported dead. The Tripoli-based internationally recognized government reported that a 5-year-old boy was killed
column7: and his three siblings seriously injured
column8: in shelling of the Tariq al-Soor neighborhood; separately
column9: a 66-year-old women was killed
column11: in the Abu Salim neighborhood in southern Tripoli. The Tripoli government accused Haftar's LNA of targeting residential areas

column13: saying: "Tripoli witnessed the heaviest fighting since the outbreak of the clashes with indiscriminate rocket fire on a high density neighborhood in the Libyan capital....In the past 24 hours

column1: 16 April17 AprilTwo GNA soldiers were killed by an LNA airstrike on Tripoli's Ayn Zara suburb. The GNA air force bombed a medical post in Qasir bin Gashir. The LNA was reported to have taken up positions 50 kilometres (50
column2: 000 m) to the east of Sirte. The GNA conducted an airstrike on Wadi Al Rabea

column1: 18 AprilHeavy clashes occurred between GNA and LNA forces
column2: after GNA units attempted to advance towards the Saadiya area. The LNA air force conducted multiple airstrikes on GNA targets in the area. LNA jets also conducted several air raids against GNA targets in Libya's Wadi al Rabie suburb.
allegedly supplied by United Arab Emirates

column1: 30 AprilRecep Tayyip Erdoğan voiced his support for the GNA
column2: saying that Turkey would "spare no effort in confronting the conspiracy against the Libyan people." GNA forces captured the settlement of El-Sbeaa (Espiaa)

column2: an Mirage F1 aircraft was shot down near al-Hira and the pilot was detained by the LNA. In a video interview with the pilot
column3: he said he was from Portugal and that was hired as a civilian pilot by the GNA. He was requested by his employers to "attack roads and bridges". The Portuguese Ministry of Defence stated that the pilot was not a Portuguese soldier. The GNA stated that the downed aircraft was not one of its own.

column1: 8 MayA clearly marked ambulance carrying the Director of the Tripoli Ambulance and Medical Emergency Services and two medical personnel was destroyed in Twaisha in Qasr bin Ghashir in Tripoli on 8 May by the LNA. The Director lost his legs and as of 8 May 2019 remained in critical conditions. The two medical staff were injured. The representative in Libya of the World Health Organization
column2: Syed Jaffar Hussain
column3: said that the attack against the ambulance was a "shocking and intolerable violation of international humanitarian law."

column1: 10 MayA number of extremist armed groups announced that would not bound by any cease-fire agreement that may be signed between GNA Prime Minister Fayez al-Sarraj and LNA commander Khalifa Haftar. Al-Samoud Brigade from Misurata
column2: led by Salah Badi who is under U.S. and U.N. sanctions
column3: said: "the true rebels will not accept any agreements with the war criminal Haftar
column4: asserting that their fight against the LNA forces is Jihad for God that will not stop until complete victory".

column1: 11 MayHaftar advanced in Tripoli's southern districts
column2: most notably the al-Aziziya area. The LNA also carried out air strikes on several militia positions in the Wadi al-Rabih and Ain Zara areas. Photos also were released showing the LNA advancing towards Sirte.
the GNA announced that Haftar's forces occupied both the Tripoli Airport and Gharyan

column2: the LNA announced that their ground defenses shot down a military aircraft of the GNA in the Jufra District

column1: 13 JuneThe LNA spokesman announced that LNA forces successfully shot down a GNA warplane which was firing at their forces in Al-Dafiniya
column2: west of Tripoli. The warplane took off from Misrata Airbase
column3: and later crashed approximately 20 km from Misrata as the pilot was returning to the airbase following the incident. The pilot was also killed after the plane crashed. The GNA also acknowledged that a plane crashed
column4: but alleged that it was due to a mechanical failure.

column1: The GNA announced that it had captured the town of Gharyan from the LNA. Dozens of LNA soldiers were killed in fighting in the town
column2: and at least 18 others were reportedly captured by the GNA. The GNA's airforce attacked convoys of LNA troops as they withdrew from the area.

column1: An airstrike by the LNA hit the Tajoura Detention Center outside Tripoli
column2: Libya
column3: while hundreds of people were inside the facility. It killed at least 53 of them and injured 130 others. The detention center was being used as a holding facility for migrants and refugees trying to reach Europe when a storage hangar that it used as a residential facility was hit by the airstrike.

column1: 6 JulyIt was reported that the Popular Front for the Liberation of Libya had joined the LNA in its offensive.

column1: 25 JulyThe first 1000 of 4000 planned arrivals of Sudanese Rapid Support Forces (RSF)
column2: veterans of the Darfur genocide and 3 June 2019 Khartoum massacre
column3: arrived by 25 July in Libya
column4: to relieve LNA troops guarding oil installations and free them for attacking Tripoli.

column2: Ghassan Salamé
column3: head of the United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL)
column4: proposed a three-point Libyan peace plan to the United Nations Security Council (UNSC)
column5: which would "require consensus in [the UNSC] and amongst the Member States who exert influence on the ground" and require Libyans "to listen to their better angels" rather than  "[fight] the wars of others and in so doing [destroy] their country." Salamé's plan includes a truce between the Government of National Accord (GNA) and Libyan National Army (LNA) and their associated militias on Eid al-Adha
column6: along with confidence-building measures such as prisoner exchanges
column7: releasing arbitrarily detained prisoners and exchanging the remains of victims of the conflict; an international meeting of countries implicated in the conflict
column8: to stop the fighting
column9: implement the legally existing arms embargo
column10: and promote the following of international human rights law; and a Libyan meeting similar to the originally planned Libyan National Conference.

column1: 11 AugustA truce took place on Eid al-Adha that UNSMIL head Salamé described as a "substantial reduction in violence along the main fronts in southern Tripoli and elsewhere" with "some violations" and that "broadly speaking
column2: the truce held for the duration of the Eid festivities." The truce constituted the first stage of the 3-phase Salamé peace plan.

column1: 6 JanuaryThe LNA captured Sirte after the defection of Brigade 604 — a Madkhali militia present in the city — forced the GNA-affiliated Sirte Protection and Security Force to retreat after brief clashes.A meeting of 19 Libyan economic and financial experts representing diverse Libyan interests was held in Tunis as part of the intra-Libyan component of the Salamé three-point peace plan.

column2: supported by German and Italian leaders
column3: was expected to be implemented as a component of the peace process. General Khalifa Haftar refused to sign the ceasefire agreement after talks in Moscow brokered by Russia and Turkey with Government of National Accord leader Fayez al-Sarraj
column4: with Haftar stating that the deal "ignores many of the Libyan army's demands".

column1: After five international preparation meetings over several months
column2: the Berlin conference for the political leaders of states alleged to have violated the arms embargo on Libya and of other major international powers took place in Berlin on 19 January 2020
column3: with the aim of stopping international involvement in the Libyan conflict. The conference launched the second component of the three-point peace plan. Serraj and Haftar were both present in Berlin
column4: but didn't participate directly in the main talks
column5: as they refused to be in the same room as one another. They were kept informed of the discussions. An anti-Haftar protest of 150 people was held in Berlin near the conference venue with posters including "Haftar kills Libyan children".

column1: 25 JanuaryUNSMIL reported violations of the arms embargo
column2: stating that during the previous ten days
column3: "numerous cargo and other flights [had] been observed landing at Libyan airports in the western and eastern parts of the country providing the parties with advanced weapons
column4: armoured vehicles
column5: advisers and fighters."

column1: The 5+5 Libyan Joint Military Commission of 5 senior GNA-selected military officers and 5 senior LNA officers started meeting in Geneva on 3 February in the military track of the intra-Libyan component of the Salamé 3-point peace process
column2: aiming to agree on practical details of monitoring and strengthening the existing ceasefire.

column1: 18 FebruaryThe 5+5 Libyan Joint Military Commission started its second negotiation round in Geneva.
20 FebruaryAfter a short break in relation to an LNA attack on Tripoli harbour
column2: the 5+5 military track of negotiations continued in Geneva.

column1: 24 FebruaryThe United Arab Emirates is suspected to have provided arms to support the Khalifa Haftar-led Libyan National Army; from mid-January 2020 to early March 2020

column3: totaling about 5
column4: 000 metric tons
column5: to Haftar's forces
column6: via aircraft flights some from military bases in the UAE and others from the UAE's airbase in Assab
column7: Eritrea. The contents of the shipments were not known

column11: such as communications equipment and other gear. The UN arms embargo on Libya was viewed as ineffective: Moncef Kartas

column15:
which was echoed by UN deputy special envoy for Libya Stephanie Williams.
26 February
The political track of the Libyan peace process started in Geneva among 20 Libyans, from both the Tobruk-based and Tripoli-based parts of the HoR, and from the independent persons' group selected by UNSMIL, including Interior Minister Fathi Bashagha, former Education Minister Othman Abdul Jalil and former head of the HCS Abdulrahman Sewehli. The aimed composition was 13 HoR representatives from both the Tobruk and Tripoli branches, 13 HCS representatives and 14 UNSMIL-selected independent Libyans, for a total of 40.


==== March ====
9 MarchNearly 40 Syrian mercenaries recruited by the Turkish Army have fled to Italy, raising the number of Syrian fighters who fled from Libya to Europe to nearly 200.
26 MarchThe LNA captured Zelten, al-Assah, Al-Jamil and Riqdalin on the northwestern coast, further attempting to push on the Ras Jdir area on the Tunisian border.Sarraj announces that pro-GNA forces will launch Operation Peace Storm and counter-attack against LNA troops.


==== April ====
13 AprilThe GNA forces seized control of the LNA-held towns of Sorman, Sabratha, Ajaylat, Aljmail, Regdalin, Zaltan, and Al Assah, recapturing the western Libyan coast and re-connecting with the Tunisian border.
16 AprilGNA forces besieged al-Watiya airbase.
18 AprilThe GNA launched an offensive on the town of Tarhuna on five axes. The GNA claimed to have captured 102 pro-Haftar fighters during the offensive.
19 AprilThe GNA claimed to have downed a UAE drone south of Misrata.
21 AprilThe LNA launched a counter-attack from al-Watiya air base, capturing the town of Al-Aqrabiya north of the air base.
29 AprilAhmed Mismari, the spokesman for Libya's eastern-based forces announced that they will cease fire for Ramadan, after suffering setbacks during weeks of intense fighting against the internationally recognized government. Mismari said in a television broadcast that the ceasefire came at the request of the international community and friendly countries".

column1: 30 AprilThe GNA responded to Haftar’s unilateral declaration of a ceasefire by rejecting it and saying it will keep fighting.

5 MayThe GNA launched an offensive to capture al-Watiya airbase. The GNA claimed to have successfully encircled the base and claimed two enemy Grad Rocket launch vehicles destroyed and various ammunition vehicles.The GNA also claimed to have captured points south of Tripoli on the same day.
9 MayThe LNA launched a mortar attack on the Mitiga International Airport destroying a fuel depot and leaving 4 aircraft destroyed
column2: 3 of civilian use and 1 GNA LAAF Il-78.

column1: 18 MayThe GNA captured Al-Watiya Air Base and in the process seized a Pantsir missile system
column2: an armed Mi-35 helicopter and the remains of 2 non-operational Mirage F1s and a Su-22.

column1: 19 MayGNA forces extend their control over the towns of Badr and Tiji.

column2: a GNA spokesman claimed their forces have destroyed 7 Pantsir batteries in Al-Watiya airbase
column3: Tarhouna and Al-Wishka.

column1: 23 MayThe GNA forces retook two military camps
column2: Hamza and Yarmuk
column3: from the LNA south of the capital Tripoli.

column2: said that Russian Wagner Group mercenaries allied to the LNA retreated from Western Libya to an unconfirmed destination along with their heavy equipment. After Antonov An-32 cargo planes landed at Bani Walid airport.

column1: 27 MayThe US military accused Russia of deploying fighters jets in support of Russian mercenaries working for the LNA forces. According to US officials Russian Mig-29s were deployed from Syria to protect 1
column2: 200 Russian mercenaries retreating from Libya. The commander of Africa Command accused Russia of using pilot mercenaries for an air campaign on behalf of Haftar forces (LNA). Meanwhile
column3: Libyan National Army officials
column4: announced that an air operation against the GNA forces will begin soon.

column1: 29 MayPro-GNA forces seized control of the Al-Kayikh neighborhood in Tripoli
column2: near the town of Qaser Bin Ghashir.

column1: 1 JuneThe LNA recaptured the town of al-Asaba
column2: south of Gharyan.

column1: 4 JuneGNA forces launched an attack on Tripoli Airport
column2: which they captured. LNA forces withdrew from their remaining positions in the southern outskirts of Tripoli
column3: allowing the GNA to regain control of the whole city. This marked the end of the LNA's 14-month siege of the GNA capital.

column1: GNA forces continued their advance to Tarhouna
column2: an LNA stronghold south-east of Tripoli
column3: which was retaken. Bani Walid was also captured. Western analysts ascribed the rapid change in the strategic situation to Turkey's increasing military aid to the GNA.

column1: With the retreat of the LNA from Tripoli
column2: GNA forces launched an offensive to recapture LNA–held Sirte on June 6.On June 11
column3: the United Nations expressed concern regarding reports of the discovery of eight mass graves in the town of Tarhuna; according to GNA officials
column4: 160 bodies were discovered and retrieved by the Libyan Red Crescent.

column1: According to the Middle East Institute
column2: the LNA's offensive against Tripoli has resulted in an increased destabilization of Libya
column3: allowing the local forces of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) to regain some strength in southern Libya. As a result of the fighting between the LNA and GNA-backed militias
column4: both did less to suppress ISIL while creating new power vacuums which radical Jihadists were likely to exploit.

column1: Under United Nations Security Council Resolution 1970
column2: the International Criminal Court (ICC) can carry out investigations and prosecutions into claims of war crimes
column3: crimes against humanity or genocide if the crimes are claimed to occur in Libya on or later than 15 February 2011. As of 6 April 2019
column4: the ICC had two outstanding warrants for the arrest of LNA commander Mahmoud al-Werfalli
column5: for involvement in the alleged killings in and near Benghazi of 33 people during June 2016 to July 2017 and for allegedly executing ten people "in front of a cheering crowd" in Benghazi between 23 and 25 January 2018. In reference to the 2019 Western Libya offensive
column6: ICC Chief Prosecutor Fatou Bensouda stated on 11 April that the ICC "[wouldn't] hesitate" to issue arrest warrants for people suspected of war crimes and crimes against humanity. On 16 April
column7: Bensouda gave more details
column8: stating that both those directly committing war crimes in Libya and their commanders would be liable to prosecution by the ICC
column9: including anyone "ordering
column11: encouraging or contributing in any other manner to the commission of crimes within the jurisdiction of the Court". According to Human Rights Watch
column12: both the GNA and LNA military forces had prior records of human rights abuses
column13: with "a well-documented record of indiscriminate attacks on civilians
column15: and arbitrary detention" by LNA forces and evidence of abuses of civilians by GNA forces
column16: prior to 4 April 2019 attack on Tripoli.Al-Sarraj stated on 17 April that the GNA would provide documentation to the ICC regarding 16 April Grad shelling of residential areas that killed at least seven people and wounded 17
column17: for which he claimed Haftar was responsible. On 2 May
column20: stated that administrative responsibility had been allocated for documenting war crimes during the Western Libya offensive and providing the documentation to the ICC.UNSMIL stated on 30 January 2020 that extrajudicial executions had been reported "in Haftar-controlled areas in Tarhouna and Tripoli".

column1: The family of militiaman Firas al-Kikli claimed on 11 April 2019 that LNA forces took him prisoner and later killed him. Images of al-Kikli's mutilated body circulated on social media.During 15–17 April 2019
column2: rocket attacks using inaccurate technology occurred against three densely populated residential areas in and near the Abu Salim area of Tripoli
column3: and were interpreted by Amnesty International (AI) as "unlawful attacks that could amount to war crimes". Based on information from witnesses and satellite imaging
column4: AI stated that those launching the rockets "failed to take necessary precautions to protect civilian lives and civilian objects". AI identified the areas hit as Hay al-Intissar
column5: in which five rockets hit five homes killing five adults and wounding a girl; Hay Salahaddin; and the "Kikla buildings"
column6: where three rockets hit a construction company
column7: a residential building and the ground
column8: wounding two people. Thomson Reuters journalists stated that 16 April Grad shelling of residential areas killed at least seven people and wounded 17. AI found no evidence for any military targets in any of the attacks and could not "conclusively determine" which armed group was responsible for the attacks. Abu Salim residents attributed the attack to the LNA. Magdalena Mughrabi of AI recommended on the basis of the attacks that the ICC investigate possible war crimes by all parties involved in the 2019 Western Libya offensive. She stated
column9: "The use of artillery and other imprecise weapons such as GRAD-style rockets in civilian areas is prohibited under international humanitarian law and such indiscriminate attacks can amount to war crimes."On 2 May
column10: BBC Arabic published its enquiry into apparent war crimes carried out during the attack on Tripoli that had been widely circulated on Facebook. BBC Arabic reported on the murder of three prisoners of war and on a special forces group of the LNA that distributed videos and photos of mutilated bodies.On 18 May
column11: a station of the Great Man-Made River project was attacked by an armed group
column12: putting at risk water supplies to Tripoli and Gharyan. Maria do Valle Ribeiro
column13: the United Nations Humanitarian Coordinator for Libya
column14: said that as an attack against critical civilian infrastructure
column15: the incident could qualify as a war crime. The attackers claimed to be Haftar supporters and their commander was claimed to be Khalifa Ehnaish
column16: loyal to Haftar. The LNA denied command responsibility for the attack.On 2 July 2019
column17: an airstrike hit the Tajoura Detention Center outside Tripoli
column18: while hundreds of people were inside the facility. It killed at least 53 of them and injured 130 others. UNSMIL suspected that the mass killing of civilians was a war crime.On 27 July 2019
column19: an airstrike on a field hospital near the capital Tripoli killed five doctors
column20: and wounded seven other people. The attack is believed to have been carried out by LNA aircraft.On 4 August
column21: an airstrike by the LNA against a wedding in Murzuk killed 43 people and injured 60. The European External Action Service commented on the civilian deaths at Murzuk and referred to the legal principle that "indiscriminate attacks on densely populated residential areas" may constitute war crimes.UNSMIL described 18 November aerial attack on a biscuit factory at Wadi Rabi'a in Tripoli

column4: mass murder
column5: indiscriminate destruction of civilian property and genocide".

column2: two thousand people protested on the streets of Tripoli and Misrata opposing the LNA military attack on Tripoli. Protestors objected against what they claimed was backing for the attack by France
column3: the United Arab Emirates
column4: and Saudi Arabia

column6: Tripoli

column8: in particular against that of France. Some of 19 April protestors wore reflective vests that Agence France Presse associated with the yellow vests movement. One of these carried a poster stating
column9: "Surprised by the French response to the attack on Tripoli" ("Surpris par la conduite française face à l'attaque de Tripoli"). Protests in Martyrs' Square continued on 26 April
column10: the third Friday in a row.Street protests against Haftar and the LNA continued in Tripoli and Misrata on 3 May. Tripoli protestors directly criticised what they claimed was French support for Haftar and the LNA
column11: with some carrying posters showing French president Emmanuel Macron crossed out in red. Several protestors wore yellow vests to symbolise their opposition to French authorities.Protests in Martyrs' Square were again held on 27 September
column12: protesting against the attack on Tripoli and against foreign intervention by France
column15: and again on 18 October. Participants in 18 October protest condemned the LNA bombing of the al-Furnaj area that killed three children

column14: stating that "the fight toward terrorism"..."allows the establishment of a stable and sovereign civil state

column18: the United States withdrew an unspecified contingent of United States Africa Command forces from Libya. India evacuated 15 Central Reserve Police Force peacekeepers to Tunisia. The UN called for a two-hour ceasefire to evacuate wounded soldiers and civilians. Meanwhile
column19: Russia vetoed a UN Security Council resolution that would have called on the LNA to end their advance on Tripoli
column20: stating that any such resolution should apply to all parties and not just the LNA in particular.On 9 April

column28: stating that Donald Trump "recognized Field Marshal Haftar's significant role in fighting terrorism and securing Libya's oil resources."In a joint statement released on July 16
